author: @TheErikaShow
text:
I used to want boobs for years‚Ä¶.then‚Ä¶.a woman I knew died from bad anesthesia. It was so friggin awful. She had four kids‚Ä¶handsome husband‚Ä¶nice homey home‚Ä¶üò¢.  She told her sister she was done having kids‚Ä¶so she had earned her mommy make-over. The surgeon was a friend of the family, so the trust was just there. She came home from surgery with ‚Äúno issues‚Äù‚Ä¶.went to bed. When her husband checked on her, she wasn‚Äôt breathing. The poor woman was brain dead from lack of oxygen. It was so tragic, I could hardly stand it.  They had her on life support for a few days, but her ‚Äúcare directive‚Äù dictated that she did not want to be kept alive once pronounced brain dead. I am not privy to how they dealt with the doctor, as he was so close to the family. All I know is that a healthy woman died after building such a beautiful life. I still think about that woman all the time. She is the reason I am still a 32B. 

I‚Äôm built for speed! üòÇ Small booty, small chest‚Ä¶.aerodynamic‚Ä¶and I can swin like a SHARK‚Ä¶lol. Just wanted to end on a positive note. üíñ

author: @mellowthm566
text:
I'm black trans femme and shave my head beautiful and bald. The comments I get are weird as hell from "yes queen" to "you  intimidating" ," bitch" or "you uhhh go to gym?".  I hate how people project their perceptions as things people push out (vibes) versus things to people actively read onto others. I'm too autistic for this bullshit üòÖ. Just let me gender in peace and forget that others perceive me no need for reminders. 

One key difference i see in getting work done is there's gender affirmation and then there's gender conformity. It's very difficult to seperate and often you can't. With cis folk conforming to trends it's clear they are conforming to some manufactured beauty ideal under the patriarchal white gaze, even if that's not there goal the gaze persists. Even so there are cis people who feel dissonance in their appearance and gender, more cis women get hair removal than trans woman ( in total not percentage obviously). On the other hand trans people even if we're doing the best to just affirm ourselves and chase euphoria we can't escape survival under a colonial binary. There's always a pressure to conform out of survival than actual desire. And a lot of those colonial standards be racist as hell, I think the Williams sisters are amazing athletes and beautiful and even their gender is precarious under white supremacy. Makes it a lot easier to throw up my hands and say fuck it I'll do my own thing.

author: @genesisjames5409
text:
What makes this issue problematic is that it seems more folks seek body modifications because of the social rewards than because they just like a certain look. One gets real tangible rewards‚Äîmoney, jobs, relationships, visibility, passing, etc‚Äîbased on their looks. AND one also gets treated with respect (although it can be superficial and short-lived). 

Being ‚Äúugly‚Äù wouldn‚Äôt be so bad if one wasn‚Äôt dismissed, ignored, passed over, and treated like sh*t. We don‚Äôt have to talk badly about each other. Men don‚Äôt have to ignore the ugly girl while they address the cute one. Kids shouldn‚Äôt be ostracized because of their features or class (which are things they don‚Äôt have control over anyway). Being told that you‚Äôre not worthy of anything‚Äîpeople‚Äôs interest, time, kindness, let alone a job or other elevating responsibility‚Äîbecause you‚Äôre not ‚Äúattractive‚Äù is heartbreaking. 

Who and what is attractive will always be subjective but basic human decency and respect should not be.

replies.text: ‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã@814Raised overweight does not equal unhealthy. Also stick thin doesn't either. People don't have nuance to what healthy bodies look like anymore. So they assume that ppl lack self control even when their body is thicker. It affects fat people but also people with average mobile healthy bodies. Not everyone wants 6 pack and bbl, or to be super thin just to look good in clothes. Average/normal weight people are told they are undesirable and undisciplined even though the BMI is healthy or slightly above or below that threshold. What we need to do is stop judging people based off their body.

replies.author: @incendiarypoprocks8700
replies.text:
@814Raised if you‚Äôre not a doctor evaluating a person‚Äôs labs and working in-person with them, it‚Äôs unreasonable and unethical do even try to diagnose someone‚Äôs comprehensive health from their visual weight alone. That‚Äôs the cause of an epidemic of negative health outcomes faced by droves of people who don‚Äôt meet conventional beauty standards or face colorism from a variety of professionals and non-professionals who then gatekeep their access to healthcare.

Either get a medical license and work directly with patients, or stop talking about people‚Äôs bodies and who‚Äôs ‚Äúhealth‚Äù or ‚Äúunhealthy‚Äù based on nothing but tv-brainrot-induced fatphobia.

author: @puc-puggy
text: 6:56 maurice is ON it! bodily autonomy!! making the decision to change your body structurally SAFE is so important. like w BBLs. a bunch of girls got them and didn't know it's actually a pretty risky procedure! no informed consent. led to or allowed to believe that cosmetic surgery is less serious and it's not. what those procedures are and the beauty standards motivating them nned to stay separate because beauty standards require earlier and more complete cultivation than the point where someone has already decided they want to change their body. and that point where someone decides to change their body is the end of the discussion with them and turns to informed consent. the lack of informed consent and the inability to name it as a structural issue make discussions about body mod/plastic surgery a lot more difficult (full discussion of this begins 23:46 in video)

replies.author: @ChocoBeauty8
replies.text: It is important to note that openly discussing cosmetic surgery used to be considered taboo and was not widely affordable or accessible to the general population. As a result, many individuals sought out underground procedures, which unfortunately led to medical complications for some.

replies.author: @puc-puggy
replies.text:
‚Äã@ChocoBeauty8 ‚ù§üíØ 
i don't know that it's true, but I hope that prioritizing informed consent as a standard of care will help those standards disseminate out. like if a girl is gonna get a black market procedure, the risks/complications/side effects will be more widely known and she'll at least be more likely to hear them secondhand from someone whose procedure wasn't black market. (aside from the increased danger of black market surgeries, a BBL is also a surprisingly dangerous procedure in general. there are a lot of blood vessels in your butt and even experienced practitioners can puncture a vessel and cause clotting or accidentally insert small amounts of filler into the bloodstream.) I also hope that adding informed consent into the discussion will help make a more comfortable and less disparaging environment to discuss anti-Black beauty standards with the women subjected to them. it feels safer to talk about a problem when you're not going to be judged for how you're trying to protect yourself from it. (edit: disparaging like the Spike Lee plot in she's gotta have it s2, not this video)

author: @kalofaeee
text:
In an anthropological sense- human beings have been disfiguring their faces and bodies in the name of beauty since as long as humans have been around. Humans have always reveled in beauty and sought after it. However- it's really interesting what beauty standards have become sans the creation of the internet. Even in the early 2000s your beauty standards were fairly localized. Magazines and movie stars still very much influenced what you wanted to emulate- but you still paid attention to the stars and the movies that those around you liked. Your access to those outside of what the majority of your region liked was limited. For better or for worse- those limitations have been completely blown open.

Now the barrier to entry to beauty is much higher than it's ever been. Rather than competing with the beauty standards in your town or city, your interests or even your specific race (I'm Polynesian, we had differing beauty standards to, for example, Sweden.)- you're in constant competition with everyone in the world. 

I was also a hardcore/punk kid for most of my formative years- so the beauty standards that I felt compelled to adhere to were that of those in that community- further "localizing" my eye for beauty. But with social media the lines of what I find beautiful can be blurred as I'm constantly bombarded with what the new "beautiful" is, pulling from an amalgamation of specific beauty standards from around the world. 

Those beauty standards in the past were not by comparison "more pure" or "better" as most contemporary beauty standards are just plain racist, colorist, anti-Black etc. But it is undeniably Different than the beauty landscape we're traversing now. 

Just really interesting stuff is all! thanks to everyone for this dialog and their perspective!

author: @spliffsforbreakfast
text:
This is something I think about all the time and I appreciate yall for taking the time to speak on it. I‚Äôm happy for anyone who‚Äôs taking care of their own well being in the best way they can. People 100% should have autonomy of their bodies. What you do with your body is your business.

But I feel sad when I hear stories about people of all ages going through botched body modifications/surgeries that are purely aesthetic. I don‚Äôt blame anyone masc/fem for having insecurities caused by society‚Äôs beauty standards. But the part that fucks me up is when these procedures go wrong. Be it regret, adverse side effects, your body rejecting the work, etc.. I especially HATE seeing soooo many black/brown women flat out die or even become scarred for life. 

Improving your physical quality of life most definitely couples with bettering mental health. But please don‚Äôt risk further hurting yourself or even your life for vanity. From the veneers to the bbl‚Äôs to the magical weight loss pills/tonics.. shit I‚Äôve even seen men getting leg modifications to become taller ü§¶üèæ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

author: @fredskull1618
text:
When in comes down to it, I still feel like there‚Äôs an ocean of difference between a punker experimenting with body modification, and someone paying for a BBL.

The BBL, more often than not, plays into a body image ‚Äúideal‚Äù that is unattainable, and it‚Äôs not usually about ‚Äúexpression‚Äù.

author: @officialnonij
text: I think the issue is how we as a people view politics and our position as citizens within politics. We aren‚Äôt bystanders. We shouldn‚Äôt just care about our government when it‚Äôs time to vote for a president. We should be caring about what‚Äôs happening locally and holding all of our politicians‚Äô feet to the fire to make sure that what we need gets done. When/if Kamala gets into office that doesn‚Äôt mean we relax, it means that‚Äôs even more reason to stay on her ass and her administration‚Äôs ass about our needs. Strategy is key. We need to be strategic with how we vote, what we‚Äôre voting for, and how we‚Äôre going to hold our politicians accountable once they‚Äôre in office. Love this vid! I‚Äôm 23 Olay, so vids like this are so important for my generation to see. We need to know what the generations before us have done and what y‚Äôall are still doing so we know how to move in the future. Thank you! ü´∂üèæ

author: @C0n0li0
text: 25:17 Haven‚Äôt watched the full video so I‚Äôm not sure whether this gets brought up, but there might be a bit of attentional bias with ‚Äúseeing a lot of people going into a lot of surgeries.‚Äù There was a HUGE amount of surgery shows (including a lot of trans related shows/eps) that really focused on body modification as this artificial thing, and very intentionally displayed people who were going for those huge amounts of surgeries because someone fixing a deviated septum and then being happy about it doesn‚Äôt make for ‚Äúgood television.‚Äù Not sure if Olay has seen some stuff that I haven‚Äôt, but as far as I know the ‚Äúbunch of surgeries in a row‚Äù cases are pretty rare.

text:
I traveled throughout the northeast this summer and any enthusiasm for Trump was invisible compared to the shitshow of flags, bumper stickers and signs plastered everywhere four years ago.

Have you seen DL Hughley‚Äôs video apologizing for his previous rant against Kamala?

My biggest takeaway from Olayemi‚Äôs hateraid is that we need to remember Harris is still a Democratic politician and not an activist.

author: @sixtyblackmystictraveler
text:
I‚Äôm so naive and out of touch with pop culture that I just thought the influence of fast food was showing itself in body shapes üòÖüòÖI never IMAGINED women were having procedures.
I lived my own body dysmorphia, body shaming issues that drove me towards anorexia and bulimia which ultimately was influenced not just by a  culture that is hyper critical of women but also as a result of sexual trauma. Can we talk about that as an influence towards this bbl culture? AND for all the judgement and criticism society likes to throw on strippers, porn stars and trans women they are major players/trendsetters for this surgery culture ie bleaching buttholes, breast augmentations etc

text: We "organized" Black people need to do what we never do.  Present a platform with SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant and Time-bound) goals with accountability milestones to candidates. Yes, Trump is an existential threat but, if we don't set tangibles, we won't get what we want.

author: @seeing-real
text: Women with natural big booties (shelf, onion,  sit a cup on it kind of cakes) get overlooked in this conversation.  I have enjoyed the reduction in commentary and critique that my natural shelf booth gets. I have a very petite body with an onion booty.  The kind that was typically considered ‚Äúghetto‚Äù in the past. Now my ‚Äúghetto booty‚Äù that won‚Äôt go down even if I‚Äôm as small as 110 lbs is considered a luxury item.  I have ENJOYED this movement!  I have not enjoyed the harm that Black women have experienced pursuing my kind of booty. But it‚Äôs been a relief to walk around with this booty that used to get all kinds of gross cat calls because so many other women now have it and it‚Äôs common.

author: @Gijakhali
text: I‚Äôve been trying to rally my friends and community to vote for Kamala Harris and it has not been easy. They want to sit out mainly bc of the disaster in Gaza. They‚Äôre deeply disheartened. I wish there was a way for me to ‚Äòhand them‚Äô the nuance in this video especially since we live in a red county in central MN which might itself swing red. Terrifying!

replies.text: Their feelings are understandable so it may be worthwhile to look at Donald's actions/stances re Israel when he was in office and the fact that he actively and aggressively plays to the demands of the extreme right-wing Christian nationalist "silent majority" faction. He absolutely won't be even remotely interested in even pretending to alleviate the humanitarian disaster in Palestine because he doesn't care and it goes against the desires of the Evangelicals who support Israel because they believe it's a necessary step in bringing about the second coming. Beyond Palestine, Project 25 has something that will directly harm everyone who isn't an able-bodied straight man of financial means.

author: @MsBlackIntrovert
text: The veneer conversation is so similar to the tattoo conversation older people have with younger peopleüòÇ‚ÄùWhy would you destroy your body, you‚Äôre so young‚Äù lol

replies.author: @moustik31
replies.text: I disgree: we only have one set of teeth, whereas skin heals, scars and regrows. Shaving healthy teeth to put on fake ones is way more of a gamble than getting a tattoo!

replies.author: @olurinatti
replies.text: No with veneers you literally have a lifetime of replacements, costs, and resulting medical issues that are incurred. People are not meant to be getting veneers the way they‚Äôre getting them now

replies.author: @MsBlackIntrovert
replies.text: @moustik31 tattoos are generally permanent. Even tattoo removal isn‚Äôt 100%. Tattoos require upkeep if you want them to look good (they fade) if you don‚Äôt have much money that‚Äôs harder to do like veneers. Although veneers are way more dangerous there is risk in both (more risk for veneers though.) We can‚Äôt say we shouldn‚Äôt  shame people for bbls and then shame people with veneers. It don‚Äôt track.The sentiment behind the criticism between both tattoos and veneers is similar , in my opinion. Not a one to one comparison but similar.

replies.author: @jamabo0
replies.text: Having a tattoo very rarely comes with the risk of major health problems. Even more, oral pain is one of the worst pains a human can bear.

replies.author: @tinynuggett
replies.text: @MsBlackIntrovertnot at all similar

replies.author: @MsBlackIntrovert
replies.text: @jamabo0 in my comment I said veneers are more risky , so you aren‚Äôt giving me information that I have not already considered. I have an opinion, it‚Äôs an informed one you just don‚Äôt agree with me that‚Äôs fine.

replies.author: @jamabo0
replies.text: @MsBlackIntrovert except one saying‚Äôs intention is utter nonsense and the other is reasonable. Old heads say that because they look down on tattoos, not because of the unlikely, minimum risk factors.

replies.author: @MsBlackIntrovert
replies.text:
@jamabo0 oral surgeons are able to do veneers safely , they still might  have to shave down teeth. It was the shaving down of the teeth that was focused on saying that now they have chickadees/chickpea (not sure what exact words were use but it was some kind of name calling). It‚Äôs making fun and calling people dumb for doing it. Oral surgeons have done veneers for quite some time, it‚Äôs unsafe when you go to basement dentist not so much with actual doctors. You should be focusing on the basement dentist not the people who want to get veneers as there is nothing wrong with wanting veneers. It‚Äôs their teeth. Similar sentiment as ‚Äúyou‚Äôre destroying your body with tattoos‚Äù to me its based in  aesthetic reasoning first.

Edit: they said chiclet , referring to boxy teeth never heard that word before, either way it‚Äôs still name calling. I don‚Äôt think some tattoos look great but hey have fun it‚Äôs your body. As long as you‚Äôre not misinforming people of the risk involved with the procedures and you aren‚Äôt doing something illegal(basement dentist, unlicensed tattoo artist)

replies.author: @MsBlackIntrovert
replies.text: I‚Äôm not a holier than  thou person I make funny jokes about people too, however I didn‚Äôt say anything objectively wrong in my original statement. (I guess a case for ageism could be made if anything but it was simply the way it came off to me.)

replies.author: @jamabo0
replies.text: @MsBlackIntrovert Most people that are getting veneers now are going to unqualified ‚Äúveneer techs.‚Äù Nevertheless, having a qualified oral surgeon apply your veneers, still poses much more risk than a tattoo. When did I ever mention the wrongness or correctness of getting veneers? We‚Äôre talking about risk.

replies.author: @MsBlackIntrovert
replies.text: @jamabo0 no YOURE talking about risk of veneers my original comment wasn‚Äôt about that and didnt imply tattoos were less risky than veneers . I have a perspective about an aspect presented in the video and you started to talk about how tattoos are less risky than veneers which I know. I‚Äôm not sure what made you think I was saying tattoos were exactly like veneers the opinion I had was: Someone‚Äôs approach to a subject was similar to an approach on another similar (not exactly the same ) subject.

replies.author: @jamabo0
replies.text: @MsBlackIntrovert No ‚Ä¶.we both are. The entire conversation has been centered around what is unsafe, risky etc. so yea, you are too.

author: @greatestone4eva
text:
there's actual women with naturally occurring genes for a curveaceous butt just like theres actual women with natural boobs.

there's ppl who try to wear colored contacts because they think colored eyes look good and then people tell me i'm not natural or wearing contacts because I'm one of the rare melanated folks with green/hazel eyes.

Just like my exs they had natural beauty, i got my natural looks too.

people be appreciating a beauty standard that they dont belong to and want to be it so they modify their body to fit that standard.

it could be a snapchat filter, so snapchat body dysmorphia, or deeper like ads, but ultimately it comes from toxic comparison.

everyone wants to be better than the next girl or guy but they aint got what the other person has, so instead of accepting themselves and loving themselves as they are they either body mod or throw out the beauty standard and hate on people.
